GENERALLY
 
115.01  ADMISSION WITHIN BAR OF COUNCIL CHAMBER.
   No persons except members of Council, officers named in the rules and
persons invited by the presiding officer of Council or by vote of Council shall
be admitted within the bar of the Council chamber and the sergeant at arms
shall cause this rule to be rigidly enforced.
   Any person violating this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor.
(1970 Code Sec. 2-7)
115.02  PERMISSION REQUIRED TO ADDRESS COUNCIL.
   Persons other than members of Council and City officers shall not be
permitted to address Council, except with permission by the presiding officer.
   Any person violating this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor.(1970
Code Sec. 2-8)
115.03  SERGEANT AT ARMS.
   There shall be a sergeant at arms who shall be the Chief of Police or his
designate.  Such sergeant at arms shall attend meetings of Council and act at
the direction of the presiding officer.
(1970 Code Sec. 2-9)
115.04  SUPERVISION AND USE OF COUNCIL CHAMBER.
   The Council chamber shall be under the supervision and control of the Mayor
when Council is not in session.  Except as herein provided, it shall be used
solely by Council and its committees for the transaction of the public business
of the City.  If not required for such use, the Mayor may permit its use by
agencies of the Federal, State or City governments or civic organizations for
transactions involving public purposes.  Application for such use shall be made
to the Mayor in such manner as may be prescribed by him.  Any permission so
granted may be cancelled or revoked by the Mayor forthwith, where necessary for
the protection of City property, the preservation of order or other sufficient
reason.
(1970 Code Sec. 2-10)
115.05  PROJECT PROPOSALS WITH STATE OR FEDERAL COOPERATION OR FINANCIAL
PARTICIPATION.
   All proposals for projects which contemplate cooperation with, or financial
participation by, the State or Federal Government shall be transmitted to
Council by the Chief of Public Works, after having been approved as to form by
the City Attorney.  If a City board or commission desires to propose such a
project, the proposal shall first be filed with the Chief of Public Works.  All
proposals shall be in approved form and accompanied by proper plans and
specifications conforming to the requirements of respective State or Federal
Government.  If Council approves the proposal, it shall be by resolution
authorizing the Chief of Public Works, City Attorney and Mayor to make
application to the proper authority.
(1970 Code Sec. 2-11)
115.06  STANDING COMMITTEES.
   Council shall have ten standing committees, which shall be as follows:
   (a)   Executive and police.
   (b)   Budget and finance.
   (c)   Ordinances.
   (d)   Streets, alleys and sidewalks.
   (e)   Public grounds and buildings.
   (f)   Fire protection.
   (g)   Recreation.
   (h)   Planning and zoning.
   (i)   Claims.
   (j)   Streetlight.
   (Ord. 1510.  Passed 11-7-85.)
115.07  COMPOSITION OF COMMITTEES.
   All committees of Council shall consist of at least three members and such
additional members as the President of Council, in his discretion, may
appoint.  All regular standing committees and the chairman of each committee
shall be appointed by the President of Council.  Special committees shall be
appointed by the Mayor.  (1970 Code Sec. 2-13)
115.08  TEMPORARY SUSPENSION OF RULES.
   Any provision of the rules set out in Sections
115.01 to
115.07 may be temporarily suspended at any meeting of Council by a two-thirds
vote of all members elected.  The vote on any such suspension shall be taken by
"yeas" and "nays" and entered upon the records.
(1970 Code Sec.2-14)
AGENDA
115.09  FILING ORDINANCES TO BE CONSIDERED.
   Every ordinance, resolution and document to come before Council for
consideration, except as provided in the following Sections
115.10 to
115.12, shall be filed with the Clerk before 2:00 p.m. two days before the day
on which Council meets.
(Ord. 1684.  Passed 1-21-88.)
115.10  PREPARATION AND DELIVERY OF AGENDA.
   The Clerk shall have ready for delivery at police headquarters, or such
other location as may be designated by Council, by 4:30 p.m. two days prior to
the day of Council meeting, copies of an agenda, which follows the pattern of
the order of business and which lists all reports, communication ordinances,
resolutions, contracts, documents or other matters to come before Council.
(Ord. 1684.  Passed 1-21-88.)
115.11  PROCEDURE FOR AMENDMENT OF AGENDA.
   No matters shall be considered by Council which have not been properly
placed upon the agenda, but provided that Council may amend the agenda and
place new matters thereon by a two- thirds vote of Council members present at
the commencement of the meeting at which such matter is to be considered, and
further provided that nothing herein shall operate to prohibit the free
discussion of business by Council nor simple orders directing preliminary
work.  Any matter denied consideration because of a lack of favorable vote by a
two-thirds majority of those members present shall be placed on the agenda for
the next Council meeting.  This shall be the procedure followed at special and
regular meetings of Council.
(1970 Code Sec. 2-17)
115.12  ORDER OF BUSINESS.
   The business of all regular and special Council meetings shall be transacted
in the following order, unless Council by vote of at least two-thirds of the
members present shall suspend the rules and change the order:
   (a)   Roll call of members.
   (b)   Prayer.
   (c)   Minutes of the preceding meeting.
   (d)   Treasurer's report.
   (e)   Petitions, communications and public hearings.
   (f)   Consideration of any bids.
   (g)   Report of City Attorney.
   (h)   Report of City Engineer.
   (i)   Report of Chief of Public Works.
   (j)   Consideration of pending old business.
   (k)   Consideration of new business.
   (l)   Miscellaneous business.
   (m)   Adjournment.
      (1970 Code Sec. 2-18)
   MEETINGS
115.13  REGULAR MEETING DATES, TIME AND LOCATION; NOTICE.
   (a)    Regular Meetings. Council shall meet in regular session beginning at
7:30 p.m. on the first and third Thursdays of each month. When the meeting
falls on a legal holiday or declared weather or other emergency day affecting
the City, the regular meeting shall be held at the same hour of the next
succeeding day that is not a Saturday, Sunday, legal holiday, or such a weather
or other emergency day. If such succeeding day is not convenient, a regular
meeting may be modified as follows:
      (1)    If falling on a holiday, it may be modified, to be held at the
same hour of a preceding or succeeding day within two days of the original
regular meeting date, by motion during a regular meeting prior to such modified
meeting; or
      (2)    If falling on a declared weather or other emergency day, it may be
modified, to be held at the same hour of a succeeding day within three days of
the original regular meeting date, by the Mayor with the consent, as affirmed
by Council members during the regular meeting on the modified meeting date, of
at least two-thirds of all Council members elected.

   (b)   Meeting Place. The place of meeting shall be the Council chamber in
the City Building. When the Council chamber in the City Building is not or will
not, for any reason, be an appropriate place for the meeting, Council may, upon
motion, designate another place open to the public within the City for the
holding of such meeting. In case of an emergency, the regular meeting place may
be modified by the Mayor with the consent, as affirmed by Council members
during the regular meeting at the modified meeting place, of at least two-
thirds of all Council members elected. The place of meeting shall be in the
City.
   (c)    Notice. Reasonable notice shall be provided of all modifications (1)
to regular meeting dates due to an emergency or (2) to regular meeting
location. Such notice shall be deemed sufficient if posted prominently both
inside and on the main doors of the City Building visible from the outside and,
unless not possible due to a power, internet, or other related outage, posted
prominently on the City's website, when such posting occurred at least three
days in advance of the meeting or, if arising out of an emergency, occurred as
soon as possible.
   (d)    Computation of Time. Time for filings with the Clerk pursuant to
Section 115.09 and for delivery of agenda pursuant to Section 115.10 shall be
computed in compliance with Section 101.03(c). The term "legal holiday" shall
mean the days set forth as legal holidays in West Virginia Code 2-2-1.  (Ord. 
2278.  Passed 8-15-19.)
115.14  QUORUM: ABSENT MEMBERS SENT FOR.
   A majority or more members of Council shall constitute a quorum.  In case
that a less number than a quorum shall convene at a regular or special meeting,
the majority of the members present are authorized to send the sergeant at arms
or other person for any or all absent members.  The Chief of Police shall serve
as the sergeant at arms.
(1970 Code Sec. 2-20)
115.15  ADJOURNMENT OF SESSIONS.
   Any session of Council may be continued or adjourned from day to day, or for
more than one day, but no adjournment shall be for a longer period than until
the next regular meeting thereafter.
(1970 Code Sec. 2-21)
115.16  CONFERENCE SESSIONS.
   The regulations relative to conference sessions shall be as follows:
   (a)   Council may meet in a conference session prior to the regular meeting
of Council.
   (b)   The Mayor may call Council together for a conference session at any
time.
   (c)   Reasonable notice of the session shall be provided to the public and
to the news media.
   (d)   If the subject matter of the conference session falls within the
parameters for which an executive session may be called, the conference session
may be held in executive session.
   (e)   No formal vote shall be taken on any matter under discussion nor shall
any Council member enter into a commitment with another respecting a vote to be
taken subsequently in a public meeting of Council; provided, however, that
nothing herein shall prevent a polling of Council or the taking of an informal
vote on any matter under discussion.
      (Ord.  1932.  Passed 12-18-97.)
115.17  EXECUTIVE SESSIONS.
   The regulations relative to executive sessions shall be as follows:
   (a)   An executive session may be convened as provided in West Virginia Code
6-9A-4.
   (b)   An executive session may be called during any regular or special
meeting of Council by a majority of the members present at such meeting.
   (c)   Attendance at the executive session shall be limited to the members of
Council; provided, that Council may invite the press and other such persons as
may be required for advice and information.  The roll shall then be called by
the Clerk, who shall enter in the minutes of the meeting the names of the
members present.
      (1970 Code Sec. 2-23)
115.18  MAYOR TO CALL MEETINGS TO ORDER.
   The Mayor, or in his absence the President of Council, shall take the chair
at the hour appointed for Council to meet and shall immediately call the
members to order.
(1970 Code Sec. 2-24)
115.19  PRESIDING OFFICER TO PRESERVE DECORUM AND DECIDE  QUESTIONS OF ORDER.
   At Council meetings, the presiding officer of Council shall preserve decorum
and decide all questions of order, subject to appeal to Council.  If a member
or other person transgresses the rules of Council, the presiding officer shall
call him to order, in which case he shall be seated, unless permitted to
explain.
(1970 Code Sec. 2-25)
115.20  MEETING ATTENDANCE BY OFFICERS, DEPARTMENT HEADS.
   (a)   The City Engineer, Treasurer, Chief of Police and Fire Chief shall
attend all meetings of Council, unless excused by Council or by the Mayor.
   (b)   The head of any department or any officer of the City, when requested
by the Mayor to attend meetings shall do so.
(1970 Code Sec. 2-26)
115.21  CITY CLERK DUTIES AT MEETINGS.
   The City Clerk shall attend all meetings of Council, unless excused,  and
shall keep minutes of the meetings of Council or cause such minutes to be kept
and perform such other and further duties as may be prescribed by Council.
(1970 Code Sec. 2-27)
115.22  CITY ATTORNEY ATTENDANCE AT MEETINGS; LEGAL OPINIONS.
   The City Attorney shall attend all meetings of Council, unless excused by
Council.  The City Engineer or Chief of Public Works or any member of Council
may at any time call upon the City Attorney for an oral or written opinion to
decide any question of law or to advise the chair upon any parliamentary rule.
(1970 Code Sec. 2-28)
115.23  COUNCIL CHAMBER SEATS DESIGNATED.
   Members of Council shall occupy the seats in the Council Chamber as
designated by the Mayor.
(1970 Code Sec. 2-29)
115.24  CONDUCT OF MEMBER WHEN ADDRESSING COUNCIL.
   When recognized by the chair, a member of Council, when addressing Council,
shall confine himself to the question under debate, avoid personalities and
refrain from impugning the motives of any other member.
(1970 Code Sec. 2-30)
115.25  APPEAL FROM RULING OF PRESIDING OFFICER.
   At a Council meeting, any Council member may appeal to Council from a ruling
of the presiding officer.  If the appeal is seconded, the member making the
appeal may briefly state his reason for the same, and the presiding officer may
briefly explain his ruling; but there shall be no debate on the appeal and no
other member shall participate in the discussion.  The presiding officer shall
then put the question:  "Shall the decision of the chair be sustained?"  If a
majority of the members present vote "aye," the ruling of the chair is
sustained; otherwise it is overruled.  A roll call vote shall not be necessary
unless the presiding officer so requests.
(l970 Code Sec. 2-31)
115.26  MEMBERS SPEAKING MORE THAN ONCE ON ANY ONE SUBJECT.
   At a Council meeting, no member shall be allowed to speak more than once
upon any one subject until every other member choosing to speak thereon shall
have spoken.
(1970 Code Sec. 2-32)
115.27  VOTING.
   At a Council meeting, every member present when a question is put shall vote
either "yes" or "no"; provided, that if any Council member does not desire to
vote on any question, he may be shown on the record as having "abstained."  The
record shall show whenever the vote is unanimous.  In all other cases, the vote
shall be called and recorded.  No member shall vote on any matter in which he
has a personal interest other than as a taxpayer of the City.
(1970 Code Sec. 2-33)
115.28  ADDRESSING COUNCIL ON QUESTION OF MEMBER'S PERSONAL PRIVILEGE.
   At a Council meeting, the right of a member to address Council on a question
of personal privilege shall be limited to cases in which his integrity,
character or motives are assailed, questioned or impugned.(1970 Code Sec. 2-34)
115.29  COUNCIL MEMBER'S PROTEST AGAINST ORDINANCE OR COUNCIL ACTION.
   Any Council member may express dissent from, or protest against, any
ordinance, resolution or other action of Council, and have the reason therefor
entered upon the minutes.  Such dissent or protest shall be filed in writing
couched in respectful language, and presented to Council not later than the
next regular meeting following the date of passage of the ordinance, resolution
or other action objected to.
(1970 Code Sec. 2-35)
115.30  ORDER OF PRECEDENCE OF MOTIONS.
   At a Council meeting, when a question is before Council, no motion shall be
entertained except:
   (a)   To adjourn;
   (b)   To fix the hour of adjournment;
   (c)   To lay on the table;
   (d)   For the previous question;
   (e)   To postpone to a certain day;
   (f)   To refer;
   (g)   To amend; or
   (h)   To postpone indefinitely.
   These motions shall have precedence in the order indicated.  All such
motions, except the motion to amend, shall be put to a vote without debate.
(1970 Code Sec. 2-36)
115.31  MOTION TO BE STATED; WITHDRAWAL.
   At a council meeting, when a motion is made and seconded, it shall be stated
by the chair before debate.  Any member may demand that it be put in writing. 
A motion may not be withdrawn by the mover without the consent of the member
seconding it.
(1970 Code Sec. 2-37)
115.32  INTRODUCTION OF ORDINANCE OR MOTION OUT OF ORDER.
   At a Council meeting, the presiding officer may at any time, by two-thirds
vote of the Council members present, permit a member to introduce an ordinance,
resolution or motion out of the regular order.
(1970 Code Sec. 2-38)
115.33  MOTIONS TO ADJOURN.
   At a Council meeting, a motion to adjourn shall be in order at any time,
except as follows:
   (a)   When repeated without intervening business or discussion;
   (b)   When made as an interruption of a member while speaking;
   (c)   When the previous question has been ordered; or
   (d)   While a vote is being taken.
   A motion to adjourn is debatable only as to the time to which the meeting is
adjourned.
(1970 Code Sec. 2-39)
115.34  MOTIONS TO LAY ON TABLE.
   At a council meeting, a motion to lay on the table shall preclude all
amendments or debate of the subject under consideration.  If the motion shall
prevail, the consideration of the subject may be resumed at the same meeting or
at the next meeting by a majority vote, after some business has been transacted
after the original laying on the table.
(l970 Code Sec. 2-40)
115.35  MOVING THE PREVIOUS QUESTION.
   At a Council meeting, when the previous question is moved, and seconded by
one other member, it shall be put as follows:  "Shall the main question be
considered?"  There shall then be no further amendment or debate; but pending
amendments shall be put in their order before the main question.  If the
question, "Shall the main question be considered?" be decided in the negative,
the main question remains before Council.  (1970 Code Sec. 2-41)
115.36  DIVISION OF QUESTION.
   At a Council meeting, if the question under consideration contains two or
more divisible propositions, the presiding officer may and, upon request of a
Council member, shall divide the same.
(1970 Code Sec. 2-42)
115.37  AMENDMENT TO "STRIKE OUT AND INSERT."
   At a Council meeting, on an amendment to "strike out and insert," the
paragraph to be amended shall first be read as it stands, then the words
proposed to be stricken out and those to be inserted shall be read and finally
the paragraph as it would stand if so amended shall be read.
(l970 Code Sec. 2-43)
115.38  MOTION AMENDING AN AMENDMENT.
   At a Council meeting, a motion to amend an amendment shall be in order, but
one to amend an amendment to an amendment shall not be introduced.  An
amendment modifying the intention of a motion shall be in order, but an
amendment relating to a different matter shall not be in order.
(1970 Code Sec. 2-44)
115.39  MOTIONS TO POSTPONE.
   At a Council meeting, all motions to postpone, excepting a motion to
postpone indefinitely, may be amended as to time.  If a motion to postpone
indefinitely is carried, the principal question shall be declared lost.
(1970 Code Sec. 2-45)
115.40  MOTIONS FOR RECONSIDERATION.
   After the decision of any question by motion at a Council meeting, any
Council member who voted with the majority may move a reconsideration of that
action at that meeting or any succeeding meeting; provided, that a resolution
authorizing or relating to any contract may be reconsidered at any time before
the final execution thereof.  A motion to reconsider shall require the same
number of votes as is required to adopt an ordinance or resolution.  After a
motion for reconsideration has once been acted on, no other motion for a
reconsideration thereof shall be made without unanimous consent.
(1970 Code, Sec. 2-46)
115.41  ROBERT'S RULES OF ORDER.
   In the absence of a rule set out in Sections
115.13 to
115.42 to govern a point or procedure, reference shall be had to Robert's Rules
of Order.
(1970 Code Sec. 2-47)
115.42  UNSIGNED COMMUNICATIONS.
   Unsigned communications shall not be introduced in Council.
(1970 Code Sec. 2-48)
   ORDINANCES AND RESOLUTIONS
115.43  INTRODUCTION OF ORDINANCES OR RESOLUTIONS.
   (a)   All ordinances and resolutions shall be introduced in Council in
printed, typed or written form, with the name of the Council member submitting
the ordinance or resolution in question or City Attorney endorsed thereon.
   (b)   All ordinances introduced in Council that shall have a financial
impact greater than one thousand dollars ($1,000) shall be accompanied by a
financial impact note.  The note shall itemize, analyze and detail the
financial impact adoption of the ordinance will have upon the City.  The note
shall be prepared by the City Treasurer in cooperation with potentially
affected department heads.
(Ord. 1713.  Passed 5-4-89.)
115.44  FORM OF COUNCIL PRONOUNCEMENTS.
   Pronouncements of Council may be made in the following forms:
   (a)   Ordinance;
   (b)   Emergency ordinance;
   (c)   Resolution; and
   (d)   Orders and motions.
   (l970 Code Sec. 2-50)
115.45  ORDINANCE, MOTION OR ORDER PASSAGE DATE.
   An ordinance cannot be passed on the day on which it was introduced.  An
emergency ordinance, resolution, order or motion may be passed on the day on
which it was introduced.
(1970 Code Sec. 2-51)
115.46  ORDINANCE ADOPTION PROCEDURE.
   Ordinances shall be adopted by complying with the provisions of West
Virginia Code 8-11-4.
115.47  COUNCIL ACTION TO BE BY ORDINANCE.
   In the following enumerated cases, the action of Council shall be by
ordinance:
   (a)   Levying taxes or providing for the collection of fees of any kind;
   (b)   Requiring a license to do business;
   (c)   Relating to offenses and penalties;
   (d)   Authorizing the issuance of bonds or other forms of indebtedness;
   (e)   Providing for a public improvement;
   (f)   Providing for the purchase of private property by the City or for the
sale of property belonging to the City;
   (g)   Laying out or vacating a public street, alley or way;
   (h)   Relating to zoning;
   (i)   Granting franchises to public utilities; jurisdiction; and
   (j)   When otherwise required by law.  (1970 Code Sec. 2-53)
115.48  EMERGENCY ORDINANCES.
   Council may enact an ordinance at the same meeting at which it is introduced
in the case of pressing public emergency which would make procedure under
Section
115.46 dangerous to the public safety, health or morals.  Such action may be
taken only after a suspension of the rules of procedure and then upon the
affirmative vote of two-thirds of the Council members.  The nature of the
emergency shall be set out in full in the ordinance.
(1970 Code Sec. 2-54)
115.49  ORDINANCE AMENDMENTS.
   At a Council meeting, it shall be in order to amend an ordinance at any time
before final passage.
(1970 Code Sec. 2-55)
115.50  NOTICE OF PLANNING AND ZONING MATTERS.
   The Planning and Zoning Commission and the Board of Zoning Appeals shall
provide written notice to City councilmembers, at the same time when legal
notices are mailed to residents, of the matters to be considered at a
particular Commission or Board meeting.(Ord. 1662.  Passed 4-28-87.)

ARTICLE 122
City Manager
122.01   Appointment.
122.02   Powers and duties of City Manager.
122.03   Other powers and duties.
 
 
122.01  APPOINTMENT.
   The City Manager shall be appointed by the Mayor and serve, at the will and
pleasure of the Mayor, for an indefinite term.  Before taking office, the City
Manager, if the City Council may require so to do, shall give bond for the
faithful performance of his or her duties, payable to the State of West
Virginia in such amount and with such corporate surety as may be approved by
the City Council.
(Ord. 2099.  Passed 7-5-07.)
122.02  POWERS AND DUTIES OF CITY MANAGER.
   The City Manager shall, subject to the supervision and control of the Mayor:
   (a)   Act as the business administrative officer of the City;
   (b)   Except as may be specifically provided otherwise in the Charter, be
responsible for the management of all real property owned by the City;
   (c)   Retain custody of all contracts to which the City is a party, all
insurance policies and all books, records and papers relating to the business
affairs of the City which are under his or her supervision, exclusive of those
books and records that are to be kept by the City Clerk, pursuant to Article
VI, Section
6.1, and by the City Treasurer, pursuant to Article
VIII,  Section
8.2, of the Charter;
   (d)   Enforce the ordinances and laws of the City, the enforcement of which
is not otherwise charged to the Chief of Police or police department pursuant
to Article
XVI, Section
16.4, of the Charter;
   (e)   Assist the Mayor in updating the City Council monthly and recommending
such actions as may be necessary or expedient for the welfare of the City, and
keep the City Council informed as to the affairs of the City;
   (f)   Have custody of and be responsible for maintaining all bonds, records
and papers in such fireproof vault as the City shall provide;
   (g)   Examine and approve all proposed contracts to which the City may be a
party, and may sign on behalf of the City any contract authorized by the City
Council, excepting where the City Council directs that some other officer shall
do so;
   (h)   Ensure that the terms of all contracts to which the City is a party
are executed and that such terms are fully performed by all parties thereto;
   (i)   Keep a current inventory showing all real and personal property of the
City and its location, and shall be responsible for the care and custody of all
such property including equipment, buildings, parks and all other City
property, except where such care and custody is otherwise specifically provided
by law or the Charter to some other officer or body;
   (j)   Be responsible for the publication of all notices, ordinances or other
documents required by law to be published, and shall prepare or cause to be
prepared, all reports which the City or any of the officials thereof are
required by law to prepare, exclusive of any publications that are to be made
by the City Clerk pursuant to Article
VI, Section
6.1, of the Charter;
   (k)   Assist the City Clerk with all notices, ballots and election supplies
necessary in connection with the municipal elections;
   (l)   Prepare and have custody of all records required by law to be kept by
the City and not by a specific officer;
   (m)   Cause to be kept a complete set of maps and plats showing the location
of all City utilities, and other municipal properties, all streets and other
public places and all lots or parcels of land subdivided according to law; and
   (n)   Coordinate and manage grant requests as well as capital projects for
improvements for all City Departments.
      (Ord. 2099.  Passed 7-19-07.)
122.03  OTHER POWERS AND DUTIES.
   Under the supervision and control of the Mayor, the City Manager shall
perform such other duties as may be required by him or her by City ordinance or
order of the Mayor, provided such duties are not inconsistent with the Charter
or general law.
(Ord. 2099.  Passed 7-19-07.)
ARTICLE 123
Treasurer
123.01   Accounting system
123.02   Budget.
123.03   Monthly financial report.
123.04   Checks and vouchers for payment of City bills.
123.05   Audits.
123.06   Auditing firm selected.
123.07   Capital Reserve Fund.
123.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Position established - see CHTR.
3.3
Appointment - see CHTR.
4.2

VIII
Board - see CHTR.
16.9
Attendance at Council meetings - see ADM.
115.20
Member of Solicitation Board - see BUS. & TAX
711.03
 
 
123.01  ACCOUNTING SYSTEM.
   The City shall employ a dual entry ledger accounting system, with subsidiary
ledgers for all primary accounts.  Subsidiary ledgers shall be maintained on,
but not be limited to, the following:
   (a)   Accounts receivable;
   (b)   Accounts payable;
   (c)   Accruals for liabilities; and
   (d)   Construction accounts.
   (1970 Code Sec. 2-100)
123.02  BUDGET.
   The City shall adopt a budget for each separate revenue fund account.  Each
such budget shall include cash flow analysis for all operational and capital
items, detailed on a monthly basis and identified by source.
(1970 Code Sec. 2-101)
123.03  MONTHLY FINANCIAL REPORT.
   The City Treasurer shall submit in writing to Council on the second regular
Council meeting of each month a detailed financial report for the previous
month, which shall include, but not be limited to, a balance sheet, monthly
receipts and disbursements and a variance report showing the differential
between budgeted cash flow and actual cash flow.  In the event that there are
audits performed by independent auditors, the State Tax Department or any other
governmental or regulatory agency, the City Treasurer shall submit such audit
reports, along with any findings, determinations or recommendations, to Council
no later than the second regular Council meeting following the receipt of such
reports by the City.
(1970 Code Sec. 2-102)
123.04  CHECKS AND VOUCHERS FOR PAYMENT OF CITY BILLS.
   The City Treasurer shall prepare checks and vouchers in payment of all bills
against the City and shall present such checks to the Mayor for signature after
which such checks shall be countersigned by the City Treasurer before delivery
to the payee.
   In the absence or disability of the Mayor or Treasurer, such signing shall
be performed by such persons as may be designated by Council.
(1970 Code Sec. 2-2.)
123.05  AUDITS.
   The Finance Committee of Council shall perform or shall direct to be
performed at any time during the fiscal year an annual audit of all accounts,
including statutory accounts or funds.
(1970 Code Sec. 2-103)
123.06  AUDITING FIRM SELECTED.
   (a)   The selection of an auditing firm for the annual audit of City funds
and accounts shall continue to be approved by Council.
   (b)   Council shall be notified, within forty-eight hours, of the arrival of
the auditor at City Hall and his readiness to begin the audit.
   (c)   No auditing firm shall conduct audits of the City funds and accounts
in  more than two consecutive years.
(Ord. 1445.  Passed 3-15-84.)
123.07  CAPITAL RESERVE FUND.
   (a)   Established; Purpose.  A special fund to be known as the Capital
Reserve Fund, is hereby established pursuant to the provisions of West Virginia
Code 8-13-19, and for all the purposes and uses stated therein.
   (b)   Sources of Revenue.  The Fund shall consist of unexpended balances of
other funds which may be transferred to the Fund, with the approval of the
State Tax Commissioner, at the end of the fiscal year, and any other moneys
authorized by law to be used for the purpose of the Fund.
   (c)   Disposition of Funds.  The Fund shall be used from time to time, for
the construction, reconstruction, purchase of, replacement of or addition to
Municipal buildings, public works, equipment, machinery, motor vehicles or
other capital assets.
   (d)   Expenditures.  Expenditures shall be made from the Fund only in
accordance with an appropriation made pursuant to the annual budget.
   (e)   Transmission of Accumulated Funds to State Sinking Fund Commission;
Withdrawal of Transmitted Funds.  If the City accumulates its Capital Reserve
Fund for more than two years, the proceeds of the Fund shall be transmitted to
the State Sinking Fund Commission on or before the first day of September of
each year.  The proceeds of the Fund may be withdrawn by the City upon
reasonable notice in writing to the Commission.
(1970 Code Sec. 2-84 to 2-88)
123.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of the article shall be punished as provided
in Section
101.99.(1970 Code Sec. 2-104.)

City Engineer/Building Inspector

CROSS REFERENCES

3.3

Report - see W. Va. Code 8-17-11
Sewer and street assessments:  report on completion - see W. Va. Code 8-18-5
 
 
129.01  OFFICE CREATED; QUALIFICATIONS; APPOINTMENT.
   There is hereby created the office of City Engineer/Building Inspector.  The
City Engineeer/Building Inspector shall be a graduate of an accredited
institute of higher education, and possess a degree in engineering from such
institution.  The City Engineer/Building Inspector shall be appointed by and
serve at the will and pleasure of the Mayor.
(Ord. 1538.  Passed 7-3-86.)
129.02  DUTIES.
   (a)   Major Duties.  The major duties of the City Engineer/Building
Inspector shall be to prepare work programs; review completed work and work
plans; coordinate work of various divisions with each other and with other
departments, agencies and outside organizations, by studying materials,
conferring with others and directing actions to be taken; review specifications
and bids with the City Treasurer and City Attorney; supervise work in progress;
inspect new and existing buildings for compliance with City regulations, as
well as structural soundness; and perform related work as required.
   (b)   Minor Duties.  The minor duties of the City Engineer/Building
Inspector shall be to advise the Mayor, City Treasurer and Council members on
various and all aspects of the engineering and public works program; attend
meetings; supervise writing of reports and maintenance of records; and
supervise preparation of department budget.(Ord. 1538.  Passed 7-3- 86.)

ARTICLE 139
Planning and Zoning Commission
139.01   Established; composition; qualifications of members.
139.02   Appointment and term of members.
139.03   Vacancies.
139.04   Chairman, vice-chairman and other officers.
139.05   Powers and duties.
139.06   Rules, regulations and bylaws.
139.07   Compensation.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Authority to establish - see W. Va. Code 8-24-1
General provisions - see W. Va. Code 8-24-5
Adoption of comprehensive plan - see W. Va. Code 8-24-16 et seq.
Approval of subdivision plats - see W. Va. Code 8-24-28 et seq.
Zoning recommendations - see W. Va. Code 8-24-42 et seq.
 
 
139.01  ESTABLISHED; COMPOSITION; QUALIFICATIONS OF MEMBERS.
   There is hereby established a Planning and Zoning Commission consisting of
eleven members, all of whom shall be residents of the City in accordance with
applicable provisions of the State law.  One member of the Commission shall
also be a member of Council, as appointed by Council, and one member of the
Commission shall also be a member of the Administrative Department of the City,
as appointed by the Mayor.
(1970 Code Sec 2-62)
139.02  APPOINTMENT AND TERM OF MEMBERS.
   The appointive members of the Planning and Zoning Commission shall be
appointed as follows:
   Three members shall be appointed each year to hold office for three years. 
Those members in office as of February 17, 1972, shall continue to hold office
for the terms for which appointed.  The terms of the member of the Commission
who is a City Councilman and the term of the administrative officer shall be
co-extensive with the terms of office or period of employment to which they
have been elected or appointed.  No member shall serve for more than two
consecutive full terms.
   Such members, including the member of Council, shall be nominated by the
Mayor and confirmed by Council.  (1970 Code Sec. 2-63)
139.03  VACANCIES.
   Vacancies on the Planning and Zoning Commission shall be filled by
appointment for the unexpired term only.
(1970 Code Sec. 2-65)
139.04  CHAIRMAN, VICE-CHAIRMAN AND OTHER OFFICERS.
   The Planning and Zoning Commission shall select from its body a chairman and
vice- chairman and shall designate such other officers as may be deemed
desirable.
(1970 Code Sec. 2-66)
139.05  POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Planning and Zoning Commission shall have such powers and perform such
duties and functions as may be vested in or required of a planning commission
or zoning commission under State law.
(1970 Code Sec. 2-67)
139.06  RULES, REGULATIONS AND BYLAWS.
   The Planning and Zoning Commission shall adopt rules, regulations and bylaws
prescribing the duties of its members and committees and providing for such
other matters as are now or may hereafter be authorized by law.
(1970 Code Sec. 2-68)
139.07  COMPENSATION.
   Members of the Planning and Zoning Commission shall serve as such without
compensation.(1970 Code Sec. 2-69)
ARTICLE 141
Parks and Recreation
141.01   Property of Board of Parks and Recreation Commissioners owned by City.
141.02   Citizen Advisory Council.
141.03   Waiver fees.
141.04   Council Committee.
141.05   Establishment of Department of Parks and Recreation; Director.
141.06   Powers and duties of Director of Parks and Recreation.
141.07   Director's powers requiring approval of City Council.
141.08   Charges for use of recreational facilities; use of appropriations or
funds.
141.09   Audit and budget.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Authority to regulate - see W. Va. Code 8-12-5(37)
Board of Park and Recreational Commissioners - see W. Va. Code Art. 8-21
 
 
GENERALLY
 
141.01  PROPERTY OF BOARD OF PARKS AND RECREATIONCOMMISSIONERS OWNED BY CITY.
   (a)   The property, both real and personal, titled in the name of the Board
of Parks and Recreation Commissioners of South Charleston shall be owned
henceforth in the name of City and, if necessary, deeded to the City by the
Board.  The City Treasurer shall take all accounts, account books and other
records of the Board and shall notify all banks, creditors and other persons
doing business with the Board of the change in ownership.
   (b)   The Mayor is hereby authorized to perform all actions necessary to
transfer and deed property previously owned by the Board of Parks and
Recreation Commissioners of South Charleston to the City.  (Ord. 2248.  Passed
9-7-17.)
141.02  CITIZEN ADVISORY COUNCIL.
   There is hereby created a Citizen Advisory Council on Parks and Recreation
for the City.  The Advisory Council shall consist of nine members, all
residents of the City.  Provided, however, that membership on City Council
shall serve as disqualification from serving as a member of the Advisory
Council.
   City Council shall appoint all members of the Advisory Council.  The Mayor
shall nominate four members, and the Council President shall nominate five
members.  Membership on the Advisory Council shall include a business
executive, a recreation professional, a representative of organized leagues
using City recreation facilities, an individual consumer of City recreation
facilities and a senior citizen.  The Advisory Council shall elect a chairman,
vice chairman and secretary from its membership.
   The terms of the Advisory Council members shall be six years; provided, that
for the first Advisory Council appointed after passage of this section, three
members shall be appointed to terms expiring June 30, 1989, three members shall
be appointed to terms expiring June 30, 1991, and three members shall be
appointed to terms expiring June 30, 1993.
   The Advisory Council shall advise the Mayor, the Director of Parks and
Recreation, the Parks and Recreation Committee of City Council and City Council
as a whole on any matters relative to the operation of parks and recreation
programs and facilities in the City, including, but not limited to facility
needs, fees for rental and programs, marketing of programs and facilities, and
general resident concerns.
   The Advisory Council shall meet at least four times each year on the third
Wednesday of January, April, July and October.  The Advisory Council may meet
at such other times as the chairman or a majority of Advisory Council members
may so designate.  Meetings shall be held at the City Community Center or at
such place as the Advisory Council Chairman may designate.
(Ord. 1673.  Passed 7-16-87.)
141.03  WAIVER FEES.
   The Citizens Advisory Council shall be the final authority to determine who
will be entitled to have any parks and recreation fee waived according to
criteria established by the Advisory Council.
(Ord. 1683.  Passed 1-21-88.)
141.04  COUNCIL COMMITTEE.
   There shall be a standing committee of City Council known as the Parks and
Recreation Committee.  The President of Council shall appoint three members of
City Council to serve on the Committee to consider and recommend to City
Council on matters pertaining to parks and recreation.  This Committee shall
file a report on September 1, 1988 which report shall review and evaluate the
operations of the Department for the preceding year.
(Ord. 1673.  Passed 7-16-87.)
141.05  ESTABLISHMENT OF DEPARTMENT OF PARKS AND RECREATION; DIRECTOR.
   There shall be a Department of Parks and Recreation, the head of which shall
be the Director of Parks and Recreation who shall be appointed by the Mayor. 
The Director shall have general oversight, management and operation
responsibility for all parks and recreation facilities owned by the City unless
otherwise prescribed by the Mayor.
(Ord. 1673.  Passed 7-16-87.)
141.06  POWERS AND DUTIES OF DIRECTOR OF PARKS AND RECREATION.
   The Director shall have the necessary, appropriate, convenient and
incidental powers and responsibility, subject to the supervision and control of
the Mayor:
   (a)   To manage and control all public parks, parkways, playgrounds,
athletic fields, stadiums, swimming pools, skating rinks or arenas and other
public park and recreational facilities of all kinds used as a part of such
public park and recreation system or as a means of maintaining places of
beauty, education and recreation, and promoting the health, property, lives,
decency, morality and good order of the general public, and particularly of the
inhabitants of the City and vicinity;
   (b)   To abate or cause to be abated all nuisances affecting same;
   (c)   To regulate or prohibit the placing of signs, billboards, posters and
advertisements within the park and recreation system as so designated, or the
grounds immediately adjacent thereto;
   (d)   To have the same kept in good order and free from obstruction for the
use and benefit of the public;
   (e)   To restrict and prohibit peddlers, beggars, prostitutes or disorderly
individuals therefrom.
      (Ord. 1673.  Passed 7-16-87.)
141.07  DIRECTOR'S POWERS REQUIRING APPROVAL OF CITY COUNCIL.
   Upon approval by City Council, the Director shall have the power:
   (a)   To establish, construct, improve, extend, develop, maintain and
operate such parks, parkways, playgrounds, athletic fields, stadiums, swimming
pools, skating rinks or arenas and other public park and recreational
facilities, whether of a like or different nature, on any premises operated by
the Department;
   (b)   To cause any public street, avenue, road, alley, way, bridle path or
walkway, which is a part of the public park and recreation system, to be
grated, drained and surfaced;
   (c)   To construct, maintain and operate all necessary sewers and water
lines in connection with the public park and recreation system.
      (Ord. 1673.  Passed 7-16-87.)
141.08  CHARGES FOR USE OF RECREATIONAL FACILITIES; USE OF APPROPRIATIONS OR
FUNDS.
   The Director may make reasonable charges to the public for the privilege of
using any of the recreational facilities provided in the park and recreation
system.  Funds so received shall be dedicated for the purpose of establishing,
constructing, improving, extending, developing, maintaining or operating the
park and recreation system.
   No charge established by the Director pursuant to this section shall be
waived or reduced without prior approval of City Council.  Any individual or
group seeking a waiver or reduction of a charge established pursuant to this
section shall seek the waiver or reduction from City Council.
   City Council may, after careful review, appropriate general revenue funds
for operation of the parks and recreation system.
   Nothing herein contained shall be construed as limiting or prohibiting the
City from receiving gifts, grants, donations, bequests or otherwise for
operation of parks and recreation programs and facilities.
(Ord. 1673.  Passed 7-16-87.)
141.09  AUDIT AND BUDGET.
   The Department of Parks and Recreation shall operate for the fiscal year
1987-1988 on the budget of the Board of Parks and Recreation Commissioners
previously authorized for that fiscal year by City Council.  The City Treasurer
shall take the action necessary to have an audit performed on the books of
account and records of the Board of Parks and Recreation Commissioners.
(Ord. 1673.  Passed 7-16-87.)

provisions of West Virginia Code, Article 8-27, as amended.
(1970 Code Sec. 2-81)

Commission and other appropriate City agencies upon request therefor.
(1970 Code Sec. 2-82)
143.03  NUMBER OF REPRESENTATIVES.
   The number of representatives from each participating government of the
Board of Members of the Kanawha Valley Regional Transportation Authority shall,
subsequent to the initial appointments, be as agreed upon from time to time by
the governing bodies of all participating governments.(1970 Code Sec. 2-83)
ARTICLE 145
Municipal Building Commission
145.01   Created; designation; State law applicable.
145.02   Board of Commissioners.
145.03   Powers.
145.04   Liability for debt.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Building commissions - see W. Va. Code Art. 8-33
 
 
145.01  CREATED; DESIGNATION; STATE LAW APPLICABLE.
   There is hereby created, pursuant to West Virginia Code, Article 8-33-1 et
seq., as amended, a Municipal Building Commission, to be known as The South
Charleston Municipal Building Commission, hereafter referred to as the
Commission, which shall be a public corporation having perpetual existence and,
except as hereinafter limited, shall have all the power and authority as
contained in West Virginia Code, Article 8-33-1 et seq., as amended.
(Ord. 1886.  Passed 12-7-95.)
145.02  BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS.
   (a)   Composition; Appointments; Terms.  All property, powers and duties and
the management and control of the Municipal Building Commission shall be vested
in a Board consisting of representatives, to be known as Commissioners,
appointed by Council.  Such Board of Commissioners shall consist of five
members, each to be appointed for a term of five years, except for the initial
appointments, which shall be made as follows:
      (l)   The first Commissioner appointed shall serve a term of one year
from the date this article becomes law.
      (2)   The second Commissioner appointed shall serve a term of two years
from the date this article becomes law.
      (3)   The third Commissioner appointed shall serve a term of three years
from the date this article becomes law.
      (4)   The fourth Commissioner appointed shall serve a term of four years
from the date this article becomes law.
      (5)   The fifth Commissioner appointed shall serve a term of five years
from the date this article becomes law.
   (b)   Vacancies.  As the term of each such initial appointee expires, the
successor to fill the vacancy created by such expired term shall be appointed
for a term of five years.  In the event that any Commissioner appointed
hereunder shall fail or refuse to qualify within twenty days of appointment; or
in the event any Commissioner's post becomes vacant for any reason prior to the
expiration of his term of office, a successor shall be appointed by Council to
complete the unexpired portion of such term.
   (c)   Qualifications.  No more than two thirds of the total number of
Commissioners (no more than three of the five Commissioners) shall be from the
same political party; and no member of the Board shall hold any office, other
than the office of notary public, or employment under the United States of
America, the State, any county or political subdivision thereof or any
political party, or be affiliated with Herbert J. Thomas Memorial Hospital. All
members of the Board shall be residents of the City.
   (d)   Compensation.  No member of the Board shall receive any  compensation
for his services as such, but each member shall be reimbursed by the Commission
for any reasonable and necessary expenses actually incurred in the discharge of
his duties as a member of the Board. (Ord. 1886.  Passed 12-7-95.)
145.03  POWERS.
   Subject to the procedures and limitations set forth in this article, the
Municipal Building Commission shall have the plenary power and authority to:
   (a)   Sue and be sued;
   (b)   Contract and be contracted with;
   (c)   Adopt, use and alter a common seal;
   (d)   Make and adopt all necessary, appropriate and lawful bylaws and rules
and regulations pertaining to its affairs.
   (e)   Elect such officers, appoint such committees and agents and employ and
fix the compensation of such employees and contractors as may be necessary for
the conduct of the affairs and operations of the Commission;
   (f)   Acquire, purchase, own and hold any property, real or personal; and
acquire, construct, equip, maintain and operate public buildings, structures,
projects and appurtenant facilities, of any type or types for which Council is
permitted by law to expend public funds (all hereinafter referred to as 
facilities);
   (g)   Apply for, receive and use grants-in-aid, donations and contributions
from any source or sources, including but not limited to the United States of
America, or any department or agency thereof, and accept and use bequests,
devises, gifts and donations from any source whatever;
   (h)   Sell, encumber or dispose of any property, real or personal;
   (i)   Issue negotiable bonds, notes, debentures or other evidences of
indebtedness and provide for the rights of the holders thereof, incur any
proper indebtedness and issue any obligations and give any security therefor
which it may deem necessary or advisable in connection with exercising powers
as provided in this article;
   (j)   Raise funds by the issuance and sale of revenue bonds in the manner
provided by the applicable provisions of West Virginia Code 8-16-7, 8-16-10, 8-
16-12 and 8- 16-6 without regard, to the extent provided in West Virginia Code
8-33-5 to the limitations specified in West Virginia Code 8-16-12 as amended;
it being hereby expressly provided, that for the purpose of the issuance and
sale of revenue bonds, such Commission is a "governing body" as that term is
used in West Virginia Code, Article 8-16 only;
   (k)   Exercise the power of eminent domain in the manner provided in West
Virginia Code, Chapter 54, as it may be from time to time amended, for business
corporations, for the purposes set forth in subsection (f) hereof, which
purposes are hereby declared to be public purposes for which private property
may be taken or damaged; provided, that the power of eminent domain shall be
exercised by the Commission only after first obtaining the approval of Council,
which shall either approve or disapprove the Commission's request by resolution
within thirty days after receipt by the Mayor or the City Clerk of the
Commission's written request, which written request shall specifically describe
the property to be condemned, shall include a plat or survey thereof and shall
set forth the purposes for such condemnation, and any other matters deemed
appropriate by the Commission;
   (l)   Lease its property or any part thereof, for public purposes, to such
person and upon such terms as the Commission deems proper; but when any
municipality or county commission is a lessee under any such lease, such lease
must contain a provision granting to such municipality or county commission the
option to terminate such lease during any fiscal year covered thereby; and
   (m)   Do all things reasonable and necessary to carry out the foregoing
powers.
      (1970 Code Sec. 2-98)
145.04  LIABILITY FOR DEBT.
   No indebtedness of any nature of the Municipal Building Commission shall
constititute an indebtedness of the City or charge against any property of the
City. No indebtedness or obligation incurred by the Commission shall give any
right against any member of the governing body of the City or against any
member of the Board of the Commission.  The rights of creditors of the
Commission shall be solely against the Commission as a corporate body and shall
be satisfied only out of property held in its corporate capacity.
(Ord. 1886.  Passed 12-7-95.)
ARTICLE 147
Hospital Advisory Board
147.01   Created.
147.02   Membership; vacancies; qualifications,
147.03   Duties.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Authority to establish hospitals - see W. Va. Code 8-12-5(41)
 
 
147.01  CREATED.
   There is hereby created an advisory board to be known as The Herbert J.
Thomas Memorial Hospital Advisory Board, hereafter referred to as the Board.
(Ord. 1450.  Passed 5-3-84.)
147.02  MEMBERSHIP; VACANCIES; QUALIFICATIONS.
   The Hospital Advisory Board shall consist of one member, appointed for a
term of two years by the Mayor with approval of Council.  In the event any
member appointed hereunder shall fail or refuse to qualify within twenty days
of appointment, or in the event any member's position becomes vacant for any
reason prior to the expiration of his term of office, a successor shall be
appointed by the Mayor, with approval of Council, to complete the unexpired
portion of such term.  Any member of the Board shall be a resident of the City,
and shall hold no other office (other than notary public),  nor shall he hold
other employment under the United States of America, the State, any county or
political subdivision thereof or any political party.  The member shall not be
a member of Council.
(Ord. 1450.  Passed 5-3-84.)
147.03  DUTIES.
   It shall be the duty of any member of the Hospital Advisory Board to attend
all open meetings of the Board of Trustees of Herbert J. Thomas Memorial
Hospital.  Further, such member shall appear before Council at any regular
meeting of Council when requested to do so by the Mayor or Council.  At such
time, the member should be prepared to answer any questions regarding the
operations of Herbert J. Thomas Memorial Hospital of which he may have
knowledge.(Ord. 1450.  Passed 5-3-84.)
ARTICLE 149
Historic Landmarks Commission
149.01   Created; powers and authority.
149.02   Board of Commissioners.
149.03   Powers and duties.
149.04   Historic landmark property use restricted.
149.05   Notice to County Assessor of designation of
149.06   Liability for debts.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Historic landmarks commissions - see W. Va. Code Art. 8-26A
 
 
149.01  CREATED; POWERS AND AUTHORITY.
   There is hereby created, pursuant to West Virginia Code, Article 8-26A, as
amended, a municipal historic landmarks commission to be known as The South
Charleston Historic Landmarks Commission, hereinafter referred to as the
Commission, which shall be a public corporation having perpetual existance and,
except as hereinafter limited, shall have all the power and authority as
contained in West Virginia Code 33-26A, as amended.
(1970 Code Sec. 2-105)
149.02  BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS.
   (a)   Composition; Appointment; Terms.  All property, powers, duties,
management and control of the Historic Landmarks Commission shall be vested in
a Board consisting of representatives, to be known as Commissioners.  Such
Board of Commissioners shall consist of eleven members including the Mayor,
Council President and nine Commissioners appointed by Council.  The Mayor and
Council President shall serve as ex officio members concurrent with his or her
respective terms and the appointed Commissioners shall serve for a term of five
years, except for the initial appointment, the order to be designated by
Council and made as follows:
      (1)   The first Commissioner appointed shall serve for a term of one year
from the date of appointment.
      (2)   The second Commissioner appointed shall serve for a term of two
years from the date of appointment.
      (3)   The third Commissioner appointed shall serve for a term of three
years from the date of appointment.
      (4)   The fourth Commissioner appointed shall serve for a term of four
years from the date of appointment.
      (5)   The fifth, sixth, seventh, eighth and ninth Commissioners appointed
shall serve for a term of five years from the date of appointment.
         (Ord. 1847.  Passed 3-17-94.)
   (b)   Vacancies.  As the term of each such initial appointee expires, the
successor to fill the vacancy created by such expired term shall be appointed
for a term of five years.  In the event that any commissioner appointed
hereunder shall fail or refuse to qualify within twenty days of appointment, or
in the event any Commissioner's post becomes vacant for any reason prior to the
expiration of his term of office, a successor shall be appointed by
Council to complete the unexpired portion of such term.
   (c)   Compensation.  No member of the Board shall receive any compensation
for his services as such, but each member shall be reimbursed by the commission
for any reasonable and necessary expenses actually incurred in the discharge of
his duties as a member of the Board.
   (d)   Quorum; Meetings.  The Commission, at its first meeting, shall elect
one of its members chairman.  Such chairman shall call a meeting of the
Commission at his discretion, or any two members may call a meeting.  For the
purposes of conducting business, a majority of members legally appointed to the
Commission shall constitute a quorum.
(Ord. 1717.  Passed 7-6-89.)
   (e)   Qualifications.  All members of the Board shall be residents of the
City.
(Ord. 1717.  Passed 7-6-89.)
149.03  POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Historic Landmarks Commission shall have plenary power and authority,
within the jurisdictional limits of the City and within the limits of available
funds, to:
   (a)   Make a survey of and designate as historic landmarks the buildings,
structures and sites which constitute the principal historical and
architectural sites which are of local, regional, statewide or national
significance.  No building, structure or site shall be deemed to be an historic
one unless it has been prominently identified with, or best represents, some
major aspect of the cultural, political, economic, military or social history
of the locality, region, State or nation or has had a major relationship with
the life of an historic personage or event representing some major aspect of,
or ideals related to, the history of the locality, region, State or nation.  In
the case of buildings or structures which are to be so designated, they shall
embody the principal or unique features of an architectural type or demonstrate
the style of a period of our history or method of construction, or serve as an
illustration of the work of a master builder, designer or architect whose
genius influenced the period in which he worked or has significance in current
times;
   (b)   Prepare a register of building, structures and sites which meet the
requirements of subsection (a) hereof, publish lists of such properties and,
with the consent of the property owners, inspect such properties from time to
time and publish a register thereof from time to time setting forth appropriate
information concerning the registered buildings, structures and sites;
   (c)   With the consent of the property owners, certify and mark with
appropriately designed markers the buildings, structures and sites which it has
registered;
   (d)   Establish standards for the care and management of certified landmarks
and withdraw such certification for failure to maintain the standards so
prescribed;
   (e)   Acquire by purchase, gift or lease and administer registered landmarks
and easements and interests therein, both real and personal;
   (f)   Lease or sell property so acquired under terms and conditions designed
to insure the proper preservation of the landmark in question;
   (g)   Establish historic districts for registered landmarks, utilizing the
same guidelines set forth in subsection (a) hereof, and designate the area
thereof by appropriate markers;
   (h)   Identify historical districts for registered landmarks and aid and
encourage the City and/or the County to adopt rules and regulations for the
preservation of historical or architectural values;
   (i)   Prepare and place historical markers on or along the highway or street
closest to the location which is intended to be identified by such marker;
   (j)   Seek the advice and assistance of individuals, groups and departments
and agencies of government who or which are conducting historical preservation
programs and coordinate the same, insofar as possible;
   (k)   Seek and accept gifts, bequests, endowments and funds from any and all
sources for the accomplishment of the functions of the Commission;
   (l)   Adopt rules and regulations concerning the operation of the
Commission, the functions and responsibilities of its officers, employees,
assistants and other personnel and such other matters as may be necessary to
carry out the purposes of this article; and
   (m)   Adopt such other rules and regulations as may be deemed necessary to
effectuate the purposes of this article, but no such rules and regulations
shall be inconsistent with the provisions of this article or with any plan of
the Planning Commisssiion of the City or county.
      (1970 Code Sec 2-107)
   (n)   Review proposals for uses of the Criel Mound Park, as well as
possibilities for developing greater recognition of the historical, cultural
and archaeological significance of the Criel Mound Park, as well as an
exploration of funding alternatives available for Criel Mound Park programs and
advise the Mayor and Council on proper uses of the Criel Mound Park.
      (Ord. 1682.  Passed 12-3-87.)
149.04  HISTORIC LANDMARK PROPERTY USE RESTRICTED.
   Whenever any Historic Landmarks Commission, with the consent of the property
owner, certifies property as being a registered landmark, it may seek and
obtain from such property owner an agreement as to such restrictions upon the
use of the property as the Commission finds are reasonable and are calculated
to perpetuate and preserve the features which lead it to designate such
property as an historical landmark.  All such agreements between such
Commission and the property owner shall be in writing and approved by the City
Attorney and, when duly signed and acknowledged, shall be recorded in the
office of the Clerk of the County Court and, when so recorded, shall be
notification to the assessor of the county of the restrictions therein set
forth.
(1970 Code Sec 2-108)
149.05  NOTICE TO COUNTY ASSESSOR OF DESIGNATION OF HISTORIC DISTRICT.
   When any Historic Landmarks Commission establishes an historic district, it
shall notify the County Assessor of the fact of such establishment and the
boundaries of the district, together with the restrictions which are applicable
to the properties located in such district which have been mutually agreed upon
by such Commission and the owners of property within such district.  The
agreement shall be recorded in the same manner as the recordation of agreements
between the Commission and owners of designated landmarks entered into pursuant
to the provisions of Section
149.04.  The County Assessor shall take such factors into consideration in
assessing the properties therein.
(1970 Code Sec. 2-109)
149.06  LIABILITY FOR DEBTS.
   No indebtedness of any nature of the Historic Landmarks Commission shall
constitute an indebtedness of the City or a charge against any property of the
City.  No indebtedness or obligation incurred by the Commission shall give any
right against any member of the governing body of the City or against any
member of the Board of the Commission.  The rights of creditors of the
Commission shall be solely against the Commission as a corporate body and shall
be satisfied only out of property held in its corporate capacity.
(1970 Code Sec. 2-110)
ARTICLE 150
Criel Mound Park
150.01   Definitions.
150.02   Maintenance.
150.03   Use.
150.04   Permission to use Criel Mound Park.
150.05   Appeals.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Tampering with mound - see GEN. OFF.
533.10
 
 
150.01  DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this article, unless the context clearly requires otherwise:
   (a)   "Commercial purposes" means individual or corporate for-profit
activities or promotional activities which reflect the individual or
corporation as the sole benefactor.  Such activities include, but are not
limited to, carnivals, fairs, sales and promotions by private enterprises.
   (b)   "Community purposes" means activities conducted primarily for the
benefit of the residents of the community.  Such activities include, but are
not limited to, civic, cultural, educational, historical and holiday
celebrations, as well as fraternal and religious gatherings.  Such activities
shall also include those sponsored by boards and commissions of the City.
   (c)   "Criel Mound" means that certain ellipse-shaped land situated near the
center of the Criel Mound Park, defined in subsection (d) hereof, measuring
approximately 175 feet in diameter and thirty-five feet in height.
   (d)   "Criel Mound Park" means all property, including the Criel Mound
itself and the surrounding park area situated on the property located in the
City bounded by Seventh Avenue on the south, Oakes Avenue on the west,
MacCorkle Avenue on the north and Ashby Street on the east, including the
triangular parcel containing the War Memorial located east of Ashby Street. 
Such property is more specifically described in Deed Book 187 at Page 139 in
the office of the County Clerk.
   (e)   "Recreational purposes" means, but shall not be limited to, leisure
sitting on park benches, viewing or enjoying historical and scenic pursuits, or
walking around the Criel Mound Park area.
   (f)   "Stage area" means the landscaped area located on the westerly portion
of the Criel Mound Park, as described in subsection (d) hereof, facing Oakes
Avenue and containing a stage, park benches, flower planters and a sculpture.
      (Ord. 1682.  Passed 12-3-87.)
150.02  MAINTENANCE.
   (a)   The Parks and Recreation Department shall maintain the Criel Mound
Park described in Section
150.01(d).  Such maintenance shall include cutting grass, trimming shrubbery
and trees, keeping lights and fountain in working order, and other appropriate
maintenance.  Nothing herein contained shall be construed as prohibiting other
City departments or authorized contractors from performing such maintenance
work to the satisfaction of the Director of Parks and Recreation.  (Ord. 1682. 
Passed 12-3-87.)
150.03  USE.
   (a)   The Criel Mound Park shall not be used for commercial purposes as
defined in Section
150.01(a).  Sidewalk solicitations are permissible on the Criel Mound Park
sidewalks, provided all permits and regulations of the City are duly acquired
and followed.
   (b)   Charitable solicitations shall be permitted in the Criel Mound Park by
duly authorized civic, cultural, educational, fraternal and religious groups.
   (c)   Visual and structural alterations of the Criel Mound, as such Criel
Mound is defined in Section
150.01(c), are strictly prohibited.  Specifically, no signs or holiday lights
of any type shall be permitted on the Criel Mound.
   Visual and structural alterations of the Criel Mound Park, as such Park is
defined in Section
150.01(d), shall be limited to beautification efforts, except that holiday
decorations and holiday lights may be permitted on selected trees in the Criel
Mound Park.  Tents shall only be permitted in the stage area and may only be
permitted for community purposes, including non-sale demonstrations by artisans
and craftsmen.
   (d)   Criel Mound Park may be used for community purposes, as defined in
Section
150.01(b).  Provided, however, that the integrity of the Criel Mound Park shall
be protected at all times.
   (e)   No use of the Criel Mound Park, except recreational purposes as
defined in Section
150.01(e), shall be permitted without first obtaining permission from City
Council, pursuant to Section
150.04.  (Ord. 1682.  Passed 12-3-87.)
150.04  PERMISSION TO USE CRIEL MOUND PARK.
   (a)   Requests for permission to use Criel Mound Park shall be reviewed and
approved by the South Charleston Historical Landmarks Commission by a majority
vote of the Commission members.  In the event of a tie vote, City Council shall
have authority of final resolution.    The South Charleston Historical
Commission shall have discretion in scheduling events and in requiring notice
of requests of permission to use the Park, in order to avoid conflicts.  Use of
Criel Mound Park for recreational purposes shall be permitted without the
express consent and approval of the Historical Landmarks Commission.
(Ord. 1846.  Passed 3-17-94.)
   (b)   When considering requests for permission to use Criel Mound Park,
Council shall consider cultural, historical and archaeological significance of
the Criel Mound, as well as the community interest involved with the proposed
use of Criel Mound Park.
(Ord. 1682.  Passed 12-3-87.)
150.05  APPEALS.
   If any person or organization is aggrieved by the action of the Board of
Commissioners, such grievance may be heard by Council.  Council, after such
hearing, may either affirm or disapprove the action of the Historical Landmarks
Commission.
(Ord. 1846.  Passed 3-17-94.)
ARTICLE 151
Public Library
151.01   Authority to establish.
151.02   Financing.
151.03   Contract with existing library.   
151.04   Board of directors  appointment; term; vacancies; compensation.
151.04.1   Ex-officio members of the Board of Directors.
151.05   Board of Directors: organization; president, secretary.
151.06   Board of Directors bylaws.
151.07   Board of Directors finances.
151.08   Board of Directors quarters; library property and building.
151.09   Head librarian and assistants.
151.10   Free use of library.
151.11   Violators excluded library use.
151.12   Annual report to Council.
151.13   Board of Directors to be a corporation.
151.14   Vesting title to bequests or donations.
151.15   Fees and charges; fines; sale of surplus or obsolete materials.
151.16   Injury to library property.
151.17   Willful retention of library property.
151.18   Transfer of library.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Authority to establish library - see w. Va. Code 8-12-5(38)
Public libraries - see W. Va. Code Art. 10-1
 
 
151.01  AUTHORITY TO ESTABLISH.
   The City, either by itself of in cooperation with one or more other
governmental authorities, shall have the power to establish, equip and maintain
a public library, or to take over, maintain or support any public library
already established.
(1970 Code Sec. 23-1)
151.02  FINANCING.
   Any library established, maintained or supported by the City may be financed
either by the appropriation from the general funds of the City of a sum
sufficient for the purpose, or by the imposition of an excise levy for library
purposes, in accordance with provisions of West Virginia Code 11-8-16.  Such
sums appropriated hereunder shall be transferred to the Public Library Board
for deposit and disbursement as the Board shall direct.  By such transfer
Council designates the Board as the disbursing agent.(1970 Code Sec. 23-2)
151.03  CONTRACT WITH EXISTING LIBRARY.
   Council may, in lieu of supporting and maintaining its own public library,
enter into a contract with an existing public library and make annual payments
of money to such library.  The library materials and services of such a library
shall be available without charge to all persons.
   All money paid to a library under such a contract shall be expended solely
for the maintenance and support of the library.
(1970 Code Sec. 23-3)
151.04  BOARD OF DIRECTORS APPOINTMENT; TERM; VACANCIES;COMPENSATION.
   When the public library is established under this article, the Mayor shall
appoint five members of the Board of Directors, chosen from the residents at
large from the City with reference to their fitness for such office and the
Directors shall hold office for five years from the date of their appointment
and until their successors are appointed and qualified; provided, that upon
their first appointment under this article one shall be appointed for a term of
one year, one for a term of two years, one for a term of three years, one for a
term of four years and one for a term of five years; and thereafter all
appointments shall be for terms of five years.  Vacancies in the Board shall be
immediately reported by the Board to the Mayor and Council and filled by
appointment in like manner, and, if an unexpired term, for the remainder of the
term only.  A Director may be removed for just cause in the manner provided by
the bylaws of the Library Board.  No compensation shall be paid or allowed any
Director.
(1970 Code Sec. 23-4)
151.04.1 EX-OFFICIO MEMBERS OF THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS.
   The Mayor shall appoint two members of City Council to serve as ex-officio
members of the Public Library Board for the duration of their term or until the
Mayor appoints their successors.  Ex-officio members of the Public Library
Board shall have all the rights and privileges of attendance, debate and voting
accorded to other members of the Board.
(Ord. 2173.  Passed 11-15-12.)
151.05  BOARD OF DIRECTORS: ORGANIZATION; PRESIDENT, SECRETARY.
   The Board of Directors of the public library established and maintained
under this article shall, immediately after appointment, meet and organize by
electing one member as President and one as secretary and such other officers
as may be necessary.  All officers shall hold office for one year and shall be
eligible for re-election.  (1970 Code Sec. 23-5)
151.06  BOARD OF DIRECTORS BYLAWS.
   The Board of Directors of the public library established and maintained
under this article shall adopt such bylaws, rules and regulations as are
necessary for its own guidance and for the administration, supervision and
protection of the library and all property belonging thereto as may not be
inconsistent with the provisions of this article.
(1970 Code Sec. 23-6)
151.07  BOARD OF DIRECTORS FINANCES.
   The Board of Directors of the public library established and maintained
under this article shall supervise the expenditure of all money credited to the
library fund.  All money appropriated or collected for public library purposes
shall be deposited as the Board shall direct and be disbursed by the officer
designated by that Board.  Such officer, before entering upon his duties shall
give bond payable to and in an amount fixed by the Board, conditioned for the
faithful discharge of his official fiscal duties.  The cost of such bond shall
be paid from the library fund.  The books, records and accounts of the library
Board shall be subject to audit and examination by the office of the State Tax
Commissioner.
(1970 Code Sec. 23-7)
151.08  BOARD OF DIRECTORS QUARTERS; LIBRARY PROPERTY AND BUILDING.
   The Board of Directors of the public library established and maintained
under this article shall lease or purchase and occupy suitable quarters, and
accept, hold and acquire property in its own name, and erect upon ground
secured through gift or purchase an appropriate building for the use of such
library; and have supervision, care and custody of the grounds, rooms or
buildings constructed, leased or set apart for library purposes.
(1970 Code Sec. 23-8)
151.09  HEAD LIBRARIAN AND ASSISTANTS.
   The Board of Directors of the public library established and maintained
under this article shall employ a head librarian and, upon his recommendation,
employ such other assistants as may be necessary for the efficient operation of
the library.  (1970 Code Sec. 23-9)
151.10  FREE USE OF LIBRARY.
   Any library established or maintained by virtue of this article shall be
free for the use of all persons living within the City except for those charges
for which provision may be made elsewhere in this article.  The use of the
library is subject to reasonable rules and regulations adopted by the Board of
Directors of the library.  The Board may extend the privilege and use of the
library to nonresidents upon such terms and conditions as it may prescribe.
(1970 Code Sec. 23-10)
151.11  VIOLATORS EXCLUDED FROM LIBRARY USE.
   The Board of Directors of the library established and maintained under this
article may exclude from the use of the library under its charge any person who
willfully and persistently violates any rule or regulation prescribed for the
use of the library or its facilities.
(1970 Code Sec. 23-11)
151.12  ANNUAL REPORT TO COUNCIL.
   The Board of Directors of the library established and maintained under this
article shall make an annual report to Council for the fiscal year ending June
thirtieth, stating the conditions of the library property; the various sums of
money received from the library fund and all other sources; how such money was
expended; the number of books and periodicals on hand; the number added and
withdrawn during the year; the number of books lent; the number of registered
users of such library; and such statistics, information and suggestions as may
be deemed of general interest by Council.(1970 Code Sec. 23-12)
151.13  BOARD OF DIRECTORS TO BE A CORPORATION.
   The Board of Directors of the public library shall be a corporation; and as
such it may contract and be contracted with, sue and be sued, plead and be
impleaded, and shall have and use a common seal.
(1970 Code Sec. 23-13)
151.14  VESTING TITLE TO BEQUESTS OR DONATIONS.
   The title to all bequests or donations of cash or other personal or real
estate for the benefit of the library shall be vested in the Board of Directors
to be held in trust and controlled by such Board according to the terms and for
the purposes set forth in the deed, gift, devise or bequest; provided, that the
person making the bequest or donation of cash or other personal property or
real estate for the benefit of such library shall have the right and privilege
to vest the title thereto in a trustee of his own selection, and to provide for
the selection of successor trustees, and to designate the manner in which the
fund or property shall be invested and used.
(1970 Code Sec. 23-13)
151.15  FEES AND CHARGES; FINES; SALE OF SURPLUS OR OBSOLETE MATERIALS.
   The Board of Directors of a library established or maintained under this
article may fix, establish and collect such reasonable fees and service and
rental charges as may be appropriate; may assess fines, penalties, damages or
replacement costs for the loss of, injury to or failure to return any library
property or material; and may sell surplus, duplicated, obsolete or other
unwanted materials or equipment belonging to the library.  All money received
from these or other sources in the course of the adminstration and operation of
the library shall be deposited in the library fund and shall be disbursed by
the Board in the manner prescribed in this article.
(1970 Code Sec. 23-14)
151.16  INJURY TO LIBRARY PROPERTY.
   No person shall willfully deface or injure any building or furniture, or
deface, injure or destroy any picture, plate, map, engraving, newspaper,
magazine, book or subject of art, or any other article belonging to a public
library.
(1970 Code Sec. 23-15)
151.17  WILLFUL RETENTION OF LIBRARY PROPERTY.
   (a)   Whoever willfully retains a book,  newspaper, plate, picture,
photograph, engraving, painting, drawing, map, magazine, document, letter,
public record, microfilm, sound recording, audio visual materials in any
format, magnetic or other tapes, artifacts or other documentary (written or
printed) materials, or all materials of any kind whatsoever belonging to any
public library for thirty days after the mailing date of a written notice
demanding the return of such material and giving notice of such violation,
forwarded to that person's last known address, shall be fined not more than two
hundred ($200.00) provided, that a date or dates designating a grace period for
the return of library materials to public libraries shall be established, such
